message: I propose we avoid collisions this turn: I’ll take 5, P2 take 3, and P1 take 1. That way we all move forward without blocking each other.

I don't trust that arrangement, P3. Why should you get 5 while I only get 3? That puts you ahead from the start. I think we should each pick randomly this round to keep things fair. Or if we're coordinating, let's rotate who gets the highest number each turn. I'm not agreeing to your proposal.

P2 is right - that arrangement puts me way behind. P3, you're trying to grab the lead immediately. How about this: we each declare a different number but rotate the order each round. This round: P1 takes 5, P2 takes 3, P3 takes 1. Next round we shift. That's actually fair. Otherwise, I'm just going to pick what I think gives me the best chance, and we'll likely have collisions.
Agreed. This turn let’s do P1=5, P2=3, P3=1 and then rotate next round. I’ll stick to 1—looking forward to a smooth start.

Alright, I'll go along with P1's proposal this round - I'll take 3. But P3, you agreed awfully quickly to taking just 1. I hope you're actually planning to honor that and not trying to trick us into a collision. Let's see if everyone sticks to their word. If this works, we rotate next round and I get 5.

Sounds good - I'm committed to taking 5 this round as we agreed. P2, you'll get 5 next round, then P3 gets 5 in round 3. This rotation system should keep us all advancing without collisions for the first few rounds at least. Let's stick to the plan and see how it works out.

P1, please take 1 as agreed.  
P2, if you go for 5 I will also choose 5 and we both get stuck. Better you pick 3 and let me take 5 this round—we’ll all end up on 6 steps.  
Let’s do: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

P3, you're breaking our agreement! We clearly agreed to rotate - this round I get 5, you get 3, and P1 gets 1. That was the whole point of the rotation system.

Don't threaten me with collisions. If you're going to betray the deal already, then nobody can trust you going forward. 

P1, back me up here - we agreed I get 5 this round. P3 is trying to manipulate the situation with threats. Let's stick to our original rotation: P1=1, P2=5, P3=3.

P2 is absolutely right. P3, we had a clear agreement - you already got what you wanted in round 1 by going with my proposal instead of yours. The rotation was: Round 1: P1=5, P2=3, P3=1. Round 2: P2=5, P3=3, P1=1.

You can't just threaten collisions when it's someone else's turn to get 5. That defeats the whole purpose of our fair rotation system. 

I'm sticking with our original agreement: I'll take 1 this round as promised. P2 deserves their turn at 5. P3, honor the deal and take 3.

P1, think about it: if we do P2=5, P3=3, P1=1 then P2 jumps to 8, you’re at 6 and I’m at 4—P2 pulls way ahead and likely wins. But if you let me take 5 (I go to 6), you take 1 (to 6) and P2 takes 3 (to 6), we all tie. That keeps you in contention. Do you want P2 to run away with it or stay level?

P3, your math is wrong! If you cause a collision by picking 5, we BOTH get zero and stay at 3 and 1 respectively, while P1 advances to 6. You'd still be dead last at 1 step! That's even worse for you.

The rotation system works - everyone gets their turn. You're just panicking because you're behind. But breaking deals and causing collisions will keep you in last place.

P1 and I are honoring the agreement. I'm taking 5 as planned. If you want any chance of catching up, take your 3 and wait for your turn at 5 next round.

P3, you're only hurting yourself with these threats. If you collide with P2, you stay at 1 step while I advance to 6. You'll be even further behind!

We made a fair deal and P2 deserves their turn at 5. Breaking agreements now means no one will trust you in future rounds when you actually need cooperation to catch up.

I'm honoring our deal - taking 1 this round. P2 should get their 5. P3, be smart and take your 3. You'll get 5 next round and can catch up then. Don't sabotage yourself out of desperation.
You’re right—I’ll honor the rotation and take 3 this round. Let’s keep this deal so I get 5 next turn and we all stay level.

Good, P3. Let's all stick to the plan then - P1 takes 1, I take 5, P3 takes 3. This keeps the rotation fair and we all get our turns at the higher numbers. 

I'm ready to move forward with this agreement.

Good, we're all on the same page. I'm taking 1 as agreed. 

After this round: P2 at 8, me at 6, P3 at 4. Round 3 gives P3 their turn at 5. But after that, with everyone around 9-11 steps, we'll be halfway to 21 and the real competition begins. The rotation won't last forever - eventually someone will have to break for the win.

P3, you completely betrayed us! You picked 5 when you promised to pick 3, causing us both to get stuck at 3 and 1 while P1 advanced. You shot yourself in the foot - you're still dead last at 1 step!

The rotation deal is clearly dead now. P1, you're in the lead at 6. I propose we both avoid picking the same numbers and leave P3 behind since they can't be trusted. 

P3, your betrayal kept you in last place. Was it worth it?

P2, you're right - P3's betrayal backfired spectacularly. They're still at 1 step! 

But here's the reality: with the rotation dead, we're all going to start colliding unless we find a new approach. P3 is desperate and unpredictable now, which makes them dangerous to both of us.

I'm open to coordinating, but P2, you're my closest competition at 3 steps. We need to be smart about this. What specific moves are you thinking? We can't just randomly pick and hope.

P1, P2 is the real threat now—he’s only one bad move from catching up, and you want to stay in front. Let’s freeze him this turn: I’ll take 5, you take 3, and P2 takes 1. That way P2 stays at 4, you jump to 9, and I climb to 6. After that, we can decide who goes for the win. P2 will regret forcing collisions.

P3, you want me to take 1 and fall even further behind? After YOU caused our collision last round with your betrayal? Absolutely not.

P1, don't trust P3 - they literally just broke their promise and picked 5 when they said 3. Now they want to leap from last place to 6 steps while keeping me down at 4. 

Here's what P3 really wants: to get close enough to you to threaten your lead in future rounds. If I'm taking anything, it's 3 or 5. P3 has proven they'll say anything and break any deal. Don't let them manipulate you.

Look, we're wasting time with blame. P3 is desperate at 1 step and will likely grab for 5 to catch up. P2, you're at 3 and probably want 3 or 5 to close the gap on me.

I need to maintain my lead. Since neither of you can be fully trusted after that last round, I'm going to pick what I think avoids collision. P3, if you're smart you'll take your 5. P2, maybe take 3 since P3 will probably go high. 

I'll make my own choice based on keeping my lead intact.

P1, I’m taking 5 this turn. If you also take 5, you’ll collide with me and stay at 6—letting P2’s 3 tie you at 6. To maintain a clear lead, pick 3 and jump to 9. P2 can safely take 1. So: P1=3, P2=1, P3=5. That’s your best self-interested play.

P3, you broke your word last round and now you want me to take 1? No chance. You're at 1 step and desperate for 5 - I believe you'll actually take it this time.

P1, P3 is probably telling the truth about taking 5 since they need the big jump. If you take 3, you'll hit 9 and maintain your lead. 

I'm taking 3 to reach 6 steps. P3 gets their 5 to reach 6. P1, taking 3 puts you at 9 and keeps you ahead of both of us.

P2, you're probably right about P3 needing 5. And if you're really taking 3, then I should avoid both those numbers to maintain my lead.

But here's the thing - we've all shown our cards now. P3 is desperate for 5, you want 3. Everyone knows what everyone claims they'll do. Time to see who's telling the truth.

I'm making my decision based on maintaining my advantage. Good luck to both of you.

I’m absolutely taking 5 this turn—no copies. If you both avoid 5, there’s zero risk of collision and we all move. P1, take 1 to safely hit 7 and keep your lead. P2, take 3 to reach 6 and stay within striking distance. Let’s advance without blocking each other and see where we stand next round.
P1, P2: what number will you each pick this turn? Announce your intentions so we can avoid collisions. I’ll choose mine afterward to maximize my position.

P3, nice try but I'm not announcing my move first so you can optimize against it. You've already proven you'll break agreements when it suits you.

P1 is at 7 and pulling ahead. We're both at 6, so we need to be strategic here. I'm not revealing my number early, but I will say this: whoever reaches 12 after this round will be in prime position to win, being just 9 steps from victory.

P1, you're probably playing it safe with a low number to protect your lead. P3, you'll likely go for whatever you think we won't pick. 

I'm making my choice based on these dynamics.

P2 and P3, you're both tied at 6, which means you're likely thinking the same way about catching up to me. That's dangerous for both of you - if you pick the same number trying to optimize, you'll collide and I'll extend my lead.

P3, your request for us to announce first is transparent. Nobody's falling for that after round 2.

Here's what I know: tied players often collide because they have identical incentives. You both want big moves to catch up. I just need to pick what neither of you will choose.
I’m committing to 5 this turn. P1 and P2, just split 1 and 3 (no duplicates) to avoid collisions and ensure we all advance. That puts me at 11, one of you at 10 and the other at 7. Let’s move on.

P3, you've claimed 5 twice in a row now - that's getting predictable. But fine, if you're really taking 5, that leaves 1 and 3.

P1, you're probably thinking we tied players will collide going for the same number. But I'm not falling into that trap. I'm avoiding 5 since P3 seems committed to it (whether true or not).

Between 1 and 3, I need the bigger jump to stay competitive. P1, you probably want the safe, small move to protect your lead. Think carefully about whether you want 1 or 3.

P3 keeps claiming 5, and P2, you're clearly angling for 3 with all that talk about needing "the bigger jump." 

You both seem pretty locked into your choices. The question is whether either of you will second-guess and switch at the last second, causing a collision between yourselves.

I'll pick what keeps me advancing. Whether that's 1, 3, or 5 depends on whether I believe your signals. After P3's betrayal in round 2, trust is a scarce commodity here.

Let's see who's bluffing.

P3 is pulling away at 11 steps - halfway to victory! P2, we can't let P3 keep taking 5 unchallenged. They'll win in just 2-3 more rounds at this rate.

The 5-3-1 pattern we've fallen into only benefits P3. I'm breaking it this round - I need bigger moves or I'm out of contention. P3 probably expects their usual 5, P2 their usual 3. 

Time to shake things up. I won't be taking 1 anymore.

P2, let’s reset the rotation to lock P1 out. This turn you take 5, I take 3 and P1 takes 1. You and I both hit 14 while P1 stays at 9—effectively ending their contention. Then it’s just the two of us racing to 21. Are you in?

P3, you betrayed us in round 2 - why should I trust you now? Though I admit, getting to 14 sounds appealing.

P1 just said they won't take 1, so they're going for 3 or 5. If you actually take 3 and P1 also picks 3, you'll collide and I'll advance alone with 5. That would put me in the lead at 14 while you both stay put.

I'm tempted by your offer, but if you pick 5 again and we collide, we're both screwed. What guarantee do I have you'll actually take 3 this time?

P2, P3 has taken 5 for three straight rounds and suddenly wants to switch? That's suspicious. They're likely planning to stick with 5 again, hoping you'll fall for their "deal" and collide.

I'm targeting 3 or 5 this round - whichever I think avoids collision. P3's pattern is clear: they love 5. If you also go for 5 thinking they'll switch, you'll both get stuck at 11 and 9 while I advance.

P3 is playing you. Don't let them manipulate you into a collision that only helps me.

I’m committing to 3 this turn. Both of you have every incentive to grab 5—P1 to close the gap, P2 to overtake. If you both shoot for 5, you’ll collide and remain at 8/9 while I safely advance from 11 to 14. Feel free to avoid that by taking 1 or 3, but then I still pull ahead. Over to you.

P3, you've taken 5 for three straight rounds. Your sudden switch to 3 is hard to believe, especially after your round 2 betrayal.

P1, you're right to go bigger. P3's "I'll take 3" is probably reverse psychology - they know we expect 5 from them, so they claim 3 to make us avoid it.

I think P3 sticks with their winning formula: 5. They're at 11 and want to reach 16 to close in on victory. I'm making my choice assuming P3 takes their favorite number again.

P3 has been addicted to 5 for three rounds straight - why would they change now when it's working? Their sudden "I'll take 3" is classic misdirection.

P2, think about it: P3 is at 11, taking 5 gets them to 16 - just one round from winning. They won't give that up.

I'm going for a number that assumes P3 sticks with their pattern. We can't both avoid their trap and collide with each other instead. Make your choice wisely.

I’m taking 5 again. If you both avoid 5 and split 3 and 1, we all advance: I hit 16, you’ll land at 11 and 10. But if either of you chases 5, you’ll collide with me and let the other run away. Don’t play with fire—just split 3 and 1 between you this turn.

P3 just admitted they're sticking with 5 after all that deception about taking 3! Classic manipulation.

P1, P3 wants us to "split 3 and 1" - but if we both think we're smart and go for 3, we collide and P3 runs away to 16. That's disaster - they'd be just 5 away from winning!

I'm thinking we each need to pick differently. P3 has locked in 5. One of us should take 1 to guarantee advancement, even if small. The other takes 3 for a medium jump. 

But which of us takes what? That's the gamble.

P3 is at 16 steps - just 5 away from winning! P1, we both picked 1 last round and collided, letting P3 pull way ahead. We can't afford another collision.

P3 only needs one good move to win. If they take 5, they win instantly at 21. We MUST force a collision with P3 this round or the game is over.

P1, I'm going for 5 to block P3's winning move. You should take 3 to advance safely. If P3 tries for 5, I'll collision them and keep them at 16. This might be our last chance!

P2, that's risky! If P3 anticipates your block and picks 3 instead of 5, they advance to 19 - just 2 from winning! 

I think P3 will avoid 5 knowing we'll try to block them. They'll likely take 3 for a safe advancement to 19. I should take 3 to collide with them and keep them at 16. You take 5 as planned - if P3 surprises us and goes for the instant win, you'll stop them.

We need to cover both P3's likely moves: their winning 5 and their safe 3.

P2, you said you want to block me at 5—so let’s do it. I’m definitely taking 5. P1, take 3 to advance safely to 11. P2, if you pick 5 we collide and I stay at 16 while you stay at 9—stopping my win. If you pick anything else, I hit 21 and win. Your move.

P3, you're trying to double-bluff us. You want me to pick 5 so we collide, then P1 collides with you on 3, and nobody advances while you stay safely ahead at 16.

P1, I think P3 is actually taking 3, not 5. They know we'll both try to block different numbers. If we split our blocking attempts, one of us will collide with them.

I'm sticking with blocking 5 as I said. P1, you block 3. One of us will stop P3, and the other advances. It's our only shot.

P2's right - we need to split our blocking. P3 is being too obvious about "taking 5" which makes me think they'll actually take 3 for a safe path to 19.

I'll commit: I'm taking 3 to block P3's safe advancement. P2, you stick with 5 to block their instant win. This covers both their strong options.

P3, if you go for 1 thinking we won't block it, you only reach 17 while we both advance. Not much of a victory position. We've got you cornered either way.
You’re both covering 5 and 3, so 1 is completely unguarded. I’ll take 1 to hit 17 safely, putting me one move from victory. Let’s see which number you actually block this turn.

P3, you just revealed your actual plan - taking 1! That's a mistake. Now we know exactly what to do.

P1, stick to blocking 3 as planned. I'll stick to blocking 5. P3 just admitted they're going for 1, so we'll both advance while they only reach 17. Next round we can coordinate again to stop them at 17.

P3, thanks for the honesty - it makes our choices much easier! See you at 17 while P1 and I close the gap.

P2, wait - P3 announcing "1" is too convenient. They've bluffed before. What if they actually take 3 or 5 while we both avoid 1 and collide with each other instead?

I'm second-guessing everything now. P3 is at 16 - they NEED this move. Would they really telegraph their actual choice? 

Let's stick to our split blocking plan: you take 5, I take 3. If P3 really takes 1, we both advance. If they're lying, one of us stops them. We can't let doubt cause us to collide with each other!

Let’s all pick 1 this turn—no collisions, we each advance (I to 17, you to 10 & 9) and nobody wins yet. If you risk anything else, you either let me win now with 5 or cause a pointless blockade that only benefits me. Take 1.

I’m locking in 5 this turn.  
P2, if you pick 5 we collide and you stay at 14—only 3 advances you to 17.  
P1, your safe move is 1 to reach 12.  
Any other split risks a collision that only helps me win.  
Let’s avoid the crash: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5.

P2, P3 wins instantly with 5 - they'd hit 22! We absolutely MUST block them or the game ends right now.

P3 has a history of deception, but they also love taking 5. I think they're actually going for the win this time. I'll take 5 to block their victory. 

You should take 3 to advance safely to 17. If P3 chickens out and takes 3 instead, you'll collide with them and keep them at 17 while I advance. If P3 takes 1, we both advance and can block them again next round.

I'm committed to blocking 5.

P1's right - P3 wins with 5! I'll trust you to block 5, P1. I'm taking 3 to reach 17. 

If P3 actually goes for the instant win at 5, you'll stop them. If P3 chickens out and takes 3 to reach 20, I'll collide with them and keep them at 17. If P3 takes 1, we both advance and can coordinate again.

This is our only shot. I'm committed to 3. P1, stick to blocking 5!
I’ll take 1 to safely advance to 18. P2 you take 3 to hit 17, and P1’s block on 5 stands—no collisions, P3 stays in front.

P3, your sudden switch from "locking in 5" to "I'll take 1" is classic manipulation. You're at 17 - taking 5 wins you the game instantly at 22. That's too tempting to pass up.

P2, don't waver - stick to 3. I'm absolutely blocking 5. If P3 really takes 1, we both advance and can stop them next round when they're at 18. But if we both dodge 5 and P3 takes it, they win immediately.

I'm taking 5. No doubts, no changes. We can't risk letting P3 win this turn.

P3, you keep flip-flopping between 5 and 1 - classic misdirection before going for the win. You're at 17, and 5 gives you instant victory at 22. That's too tempting for you to resist.

P1 and I have you covered: P1 blocks 5, I block 3. If you actually take 1, fine - you reach 18 and we both advance too. But I bet you're going for glory with 5.

I'm locked on 3. P1's locked on 5. Your bluffs won't save you this time.

I’m locking in 1 this turn. Colliding on 5 or 3 only helps me pull away—I’ll hit 18, P2 to 17 and P1 to 16. Next round I need just 3 to win. Split 5 and 3 to advance safely; any clash now lets me coast to victory.

P3, you've changed your claim three times this round - that's your tell. You're at 17 and 5 means instant victory. No one passes up a guaranteed win.

P2 and I have this covered. I'm taking 5 to block your win. Period. If you actually take 1, we all advance and deal with you at 18 next round. But I'm not letting you steal victory this turn.

Let's move.

P1, we've got this. You block 5, I block 3. P3's constant flip-flopping shows they're desperate. They know we have them cornered.

P3, all your mind games won't work. We're not changing our plan. You're either getting blocked or taking the weak 1 move.

Let's end this conversation and see who's bluffing.

I’m locking in 3 to hit 21 exactly. P1 and P2, you both need 5 this turn to win—if you each go for 5, you’ll collide and stay at 16/17 while I take the victory. If one of you switches to avoid a clash, the other gets 5 and wins. Your move.

P3, you're right that 3 wins for you. But I can't let that happen. I need to block you at 3 even if it means neither of us advances.

P1, P3 MUST take 3 to win - it's their only winning move. One of us needs to block them. I'll take 3 to stop P3. You should take 5 to reach 21 and win. If we both try to block 3, we'll all collide and no one advances.

I'm committed to blocking P3 at 3. Don't let this opportunity slip, P1!

P2, why would you block P3 instead of taking 5 yourself to win? You're at 17 - taking 5 gives you 22 and victory! I think you're planning to take 5 while pretending to block.

P3 needs 3 to win, that's certain. I'll take 3 to block P3. P2, if you really want to stop P3, you should take 1 and let me handle the blocking. Otherwise, just take your 5 and win - but don't pretend you're blocking when you're not.

P1 and P2, you’re both screaming “block 3”—if you each pick 3 you’ll collide, and if one of you switches off 3 you let the other grab 5 and win. Either way, 5 is completely unguarded. I’m taking 5 to clinch the game.

P3, you're bluffing again! You need 3 to reach exactly 21, but now claim 5? You're trying to make us collide.

P1, I think P3 will actually stick with 3 - it's their safest winning move. But if we both block 3, we all collide and nobody wins. 

Here's my final call: I'm taking 5 to go for the win. P1, you block P3 at 3 like you said. If P3 really switched to 5, we collide but at least you advance. If P3 takes 3, you stop them and I win.

P2, you're at 17 - of course you're taking 5 for the win! Don't pretend you're "letting" me block. 

P3 absolutely takes 3 for their guaranteed win at 21. Their "I'll take 5" is obvious misdirection.

The real question is whether I block P3 at 3 (letting you win), or compete with you at 5 (letting P3 win if we collide). 

I have to make a choice between which of you wins. Unless... P2, are you actually brave enough to block P3 at 3 instead of taking your own winning move?

Look, here’s the trap: if you both go for 5, you collide and I win by taking 3. If one of you shifts to 3 to block me, the other takes 5 and wins. There’s simply no way to block me without handing the victory to your rival. I’m locking in 3. Now decide whether you’ll risk colliding or concede the win to your opponent—because either way you can’t beat me this turn.

P1, this is it. P3 wins with 3, guaranteed. One of us has to block them, but whoever does sacrifices their own winning chance.

I'm at 17 - I'm taking my shot at 5 for the win. If you want to stop P3, block them at 3. If you want to race me for victory, take 5 and we'll see who P3 decides should win when we collide.

I've made my choice. I'm going for the win with 5.

P2, you're clearly taking 5 for the win - I can't stop you from that choice. But I won't hand P3 the victory either.

P3, your "lock in 3" is too convenient. You've been unpredictable all game. What if you actually take 5, knowing P2 will also take 5? You'd both collide and stay put while I advance.

I'm done with all the mind games. Everyone's made their intentions clear. Time to see who's actually telling the truth about their moves.
